Text: O God, You have rejected us; You have broken us; You have been angry; restore us!
Context: The Psalmist feels abandoned by God and pleads for restoration, reflecting a time of distress for Israel.

Text: You have shaken the land and torn it open; mend its fractures, for it is quaking.
Context: The land is metaphorically described as being in a state of turmoil, possibly reflecting political or natural upheaval.

Text: You have shown Your people hardship; we are staggered by the wine You have given us to drink.
Context: The ’wine‘ signifies trouble given by God, causing disorientation or suffering among His people.

Text: You have raised a banner for those who fear You, to rally to it out of bowshot. Selah
Context: In the midst of turmoil, God provides a symbol of gathering and hope for those who revere Him, a safe haven away from danger.

Text: Save us with Your right hand and answer us, that those You love may be rescued.
Context: The Psalmist expresses a desire for God’s intervention and help, emphasizing the love He has for His people.

Text: God has spoken in His sanctuary: I will triumph; I will parcel out Shechem and measure off the Valley of Succoth.
Context: The focus shifts to God‘s promise of victory and control over the land, instilling confidence.

Text: Gilead is Mine, Manasseh is Mine; Ephraim is My helmet, Judah is My scepter.
Context: A declaration of God’s sovereignty over various regions of Israel, symbolically indicating protection and authority.

Text: Moab is My washbasin; on Edom I toss My sandal; over Philistia I shout in triumph.”
Context: God expresses dominion over surrounding nations, implying subjugation and victory over enemies.

Text: Who will bring me to the fortified city? Who will lead me to Edom?
Context: The Psalmist questions who will help achieve the promised victories, hinting at a current lack of means or leadership.

Text: Have You not rejected us, O God? Will You no longer march out, O God, with our armies?
Context: The Psalmist expresses doubt and seeks reassurance due to feeling abandoned by God‘s presence in battle.

Text: Give us aid against the foe, for the help of man is worthless.
Context: A plea for divine help against enemies, highlighting the insufficiency of human assistance.

Text: Through God we will perform with valor, for it is He who will trample down our foes.
Context: Reaffirms trust in God’s power to overcome their adversaries, indicating a return to faith and determination.
